column4: A good primer on Calgary's historic centre by Mohkintsis (Blackfoot for where the Bow and Elbow Rivers meet).They've got some cool stuff to see, much of which is in text form. Thus, it's better for older young people if you bring children. It's very encouraging that they are starting to include more indigenous content and awareness.The Fort is...
I have been to Fort Calgary a few times I have been for the Christmas Market as well as Brunch You can go around and check the displays when you are there
A lot to read and see. Learnt a lot about the history of Calgary I did not know. Friendly, knowledgeable employees answers any questions you have.
it was more than what I expected. it looks like an old theme park, but once you get in, you will forget about it and just enjoy!
Great quick glimpse into YYC s past: stories, anecdotes, pictures..etc.If only the displays could also be in other languages (french for example...canada is bilingual after all)

Great experience. Food well prepared. Menu had two sections, from the kitchen and the buffet. Ordered from the kitchen then went to buffet.Made to order omelets.Servers attentive without being obtrusive.Large room, never felt crowded, not rushed to complete meal.Value good for the price.

We found this museum a couple of years back. For its tiny little size it is a great museum and has some really great interactive displays. We go once a year when friends come to visit and they always have veryngreatnthigns to say.

We have enjoyed several visits to Fort Calgary for fabulous brunch experiences. Reservations are always recommended, especially for busy times like Mothers' Day, Fathers' Day, Easter etc. The menu is always amazing, with both buffet and a la carte choices. Gluten-free options are extensive and delicious. Families, seniors, couples are welcome and treated well by knowledgeable and friendly staff. Friends...

As we were only in Calgary for the day, we went here to learn a little about the area, whilst still being within walking distance of our hotel. It wasn't that big but had plenty of information available. We took our time and spent around 2hrs wandering through and even had a game of pool.
The food and the atmosphere is excellent. Service is great and selection of food is wide and varied.

Visited Fort Calgary this morning. It's mostly geared towards school aged children with lots of interactive displays ect. As for adults it's still interesting to read the birth of Calgary.Everyone was super friendly, even had the security guard take my pictures.
Excellent venue for brunchGood selection of everythingRoast Beef, Primerib, omelets etcGood price point and easy to navigate as brunch goes
More a history of Calgary than a museum of the fort as that no longer exists. As a museum of Calgary it really is quite good.
We decided to go there at first during our stay in Calgary. Then we took a walk from the Fort, go along the river up to the city centre. Wonderful!

I knew nothing of the history of Calgary, and this Fort was a surprise. It was laid out as a museum, with a walking path, in a way exposing the visitor to the history and sights of Calgary's past. I remember a "pharmacy", with old-fashioned bottles of chemicals set up as they hmay have been in a pharmacy. Old electrical...

My husband and I did the tour of Fort Calgary while visiting our son. I wasn't sure what to expect but it was well worth the visit. We enjoyed learning about the city and how the RCMP came about. A must see while in Calgary.

We weren't sure what to expect, but thought there would have been some of the old fort to see. That was not the case. They have done a great job of recreating the fort inside of a new building. The history of Calgary was interesting and well represented by photos and artifacts from different periods. The area outside where the...

This is a good attraction for a rainy or cold day since most of the exhibits are indoors. There are lots of signs that explain the history of the fort and the development of the Royal Northwest/Canadian Mounted Police, Canadian Pacific Railroad and the city of Calgary. The exhibits show the what the daily life was like at the fort...

I was disappointed with the presentation of the Fort. The welcome was friendly but the map of the interior was confusing. What I presume was the old Fort had a lot of potential but seemed to be being used for meeting spaces.

Anyone who lives in the city will already know this, but for people arriving in Calgary for the first time be aware that this is a museum of Calgary's history housed in a reproduction of the fort. Interesting exhibits about how the city was founded as a Mounties post, to the building of the railway and through to WWII. There...

This is a small museum with a number of outside areas. I visited here on what was unfortunately a rather rainy day so perhaps didn't see this place to its full potential as I didn't fancy walking around in the rain more than I had to...Nevertheless what I saw (the museum centre) is pretty good. Some of the way...

Been in Calgary over two years now and I had no idea about any of its history. If you had told me that Calgary was founded in 1993 I would have had no reason to question you. I came here because my parents were in town and their isn't much else to do in Calgary. I wasn't really expecting much...

The Ft Calgary Interpretive Center is a really interesting and informative exhibit depicting the early history of Calgary. For those of us not familiar with Calgary's history, it was very helpful. There are many, many, rooms that have been decorated to depict the era being depicted. We liked the Hologram type pictures that showed Calgary at different times in its...
Very interesting and informative . Nice start to the teaching of the history of Alberta history.Spent a couple of hours here.
This is ok to do if you have the time but is a bit lacklustre. The statues and information is informative and gives a sense of what occurred on the site.

An easy 2 km walk from downtown Calgary, the museum is just that, a museum not a fort. However, it tells a fascinating but simple history of Calgary from a number of different perspectives. There's quite a bit to read, but take the time to do so and it's also worth sitting through the 20 minute film of the history....

This was the first place we visited the Sunday afternoon we arrived in Calgary. We were expecting a fort, but it really is a museum with the footprint of the original fort. Still it was very informative and gave us great history about the birth of Calgary. It sits where the Bow and Elbow Rivers meet and is a lovely...

A lovely little place to introduce you to the history of Calgary. You can spend a couple of hours taking everything in. It's kept clean and tidy and the information given is informative. There are some good photo opportunities throughout as well.
I love how the history gets put in context to the land.... ( no iPhone back then to chat while getting to a place to meet!) The land, the location and a beginning..... think about that...

The site of the old building gave me hope I would be stepping into a restored old fort. Unfortunately the museum features mostly recreated scenes more related to the time period than to the fort.We found ourselves moving quickly from room to room with not a lot to hold our interest.Definitely would not go back.

We were able to see this entire attraction in under an hour. It is a museum with a lot of historical information. Reconstruction of the original fort has not begun. When it is completed, this will probably be an excellent place to visit. Right now, old photographs dominate a large part of the museum, with some historical exhibits rounding out...

Visited with grandparents, main fort part of the exhibition really cheesy with 'social media' esc comments and likes etc on comments - really contrived, not impressed. Far too many very similar info posters made for almost immediate boredom for my 11 year old.The shops part held out attention for longer but I really wouldn't bother visiting unless really running...

This museum is a great centre of learning if you like the history of the RCMP and Calgary in general. The uniforms, Ford Roadster, and jackets were all very fun props to use and made for some great photos, but the layout was lacking. There's a ramp leading up to the first exhibit, which the front desk will direct you...

Fort Calgary was quite an interesting place to visit with a number of sections bearing good information on the history of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police on display, unfortunately the museum is small and was not enough to keep my son entertained. There was also a wedding and celebration of life taking place on the day of our visit which...

Having arrived at Calgary at the start of a three week holiday we took the time to wander along to the site of the old fort in Calgary. So okay it wasn't quite the same site but it was near enough.We met some keen as mustard seniors who explained where the venue was at. Amazing to think the Royal...

I love learning about our beloved and proud RCMP along with all the history.Fort Calgary was the beginning of Calgary itself. That alone is really cool.Lots of old pieces and things to see was a lot of fun. Got to dress up like a Mountie which was lots of fun too.Great day staff was really friendly! Lots...
This place is very well put together. A very informative place on the history of Calgary with very humble beginnings. Now a city with a thriving center.
Fort Calgary had a lot more than I thought it would- great displays and well done - makes learning history fun. We attended a special event there- period piece dinner theatre- watch out for events
My colleagues organized a lunch and tour to break up a full day meeting while on business trip to Calgary. The food was excellent and tour guide especially interesting and informative.

If you love history then it is indeed worth your time! If you're looking to be wowed by fancy multimedia displays and don't care to take the time to read lengthy historical facts, then don't bother! I found all the exhibits and the information presented quite interesting and very informative. The layout of the exhibits within the fort was well...

We spent a couple of hours visiting the museum which was very informative of the development of Calgary. However, I was expecting there to be a fort or at least a replica on the site given its name and was disappointed that there isn't one. Maybe I had false expectations and it is still worth a visit.

Fort Calgary is the location of the first settlement in Calgary in the 19th century, basically where Calgary started. There are well presented and very interesting exhibits inside showing a mock up original railway station, RCMP barracks, shops & homes of the time and much more. Well worth a visit and good value.

Our family of three got through the museum in an hour quite easily. We are usually very good at maximizing opportunities at places but overall it is quite small and not a lot to do. There is a lot of reading which meant that the 13 year old was not so interested in the museum at all. We would have...

We recently attended a wedding at Fort Calgary, and it was simply amazing. The atmosphere, the food and the service was top notch. Amazing setting down by the river. Plus we had free access to the museum before and after the ceremony which was amazing. We got to learn how Calgary became a city back in 1894 and its progression...

Most of the story is told through posts which use social media formats (so & so posted something & someone else liked or commented). I'm not sure this is the most appropriate way but it does tell the story for the most part. There were a few gaps however (I'm still not sure what happened the buffalo?!)On the whole...

An interesting museum that covers a broad range of local history. My challenge with it is that it doesn't go into much depth in any of the areas it covers, and the areas themselves don't seem to tie together really well (beyond the loose local tie). Some of the exhibits didn't really have a lot of context, and could have...

We came from Australia and this was a great introduction to the history of the Mounties and Calgary more generally. The kids loved the opportunity to dress up as a mounty and get locked up in jail. The officers mess presents the local history (and the RCMP history) in an interesting and accessible way. There are great insights into the...

Fort Calgary is a well appointed museum. I was quite pleased by the number of exhibits. You'll see the history of the area including the exploration of the from interactions with the First Nation people and building the CPR and continuing to modern day Calgary.

They could have done a much better job on this "fort." Really, it's a mess hall containing multiple placards that take you through Calgary's history and touch upon the RCMP history (spoiler: the mounties were started to keep whisky away from the Indians).For the price, I was expecting actors in period clothing, historians, and... um... something that looked remotely...

A really interesting way to learn about the history of Calgary. Beautifully laid out with interesting displays and films. Set in a beautiful garden setting and only a short trip from downtown Calgary.
I visited it last week. It was an interesting visit to know the history of Calgary.It is good for kids too.
Chose to visit as it was very rainy and an indoor activity was required. Easily assimilated, well presented museum. Shops, houses etc well recreated. Lots of artefacts.

Instead of putting historical artifact in showcases, this place recreate actual places incorporating historical items and then include stories, explanation, etc. There are only a few items that invite touching, but you can try on the uniform of North-west Mounted Police (NWMP) or sit and drive an old car. Overall, there are a lot of information and surrounding garden next...

My children and I love touring forts. We have visited many throughout Oregon, Washington, and Vancouver, BC. The kids love to cross the courtyard and enter building after building to meet the volunteer inside.Unlike the other forts, Fort Calgary is an ideal rainy day activity. The main barrack was rebuilt to look like the original. This building contains museum...

Visited Fort Calgary on a hot, hot afternoon in June (when we needed an A/C break!) Nearby Inglewood was great for brunch + shopping beforehand, and then it took about an hour to wander through the various rooms set-up in Fort Calgary outlining the history of the city/surrounding lands. Seems like something every school kid in Calgary must have to...
I enjoyed learning about the origins of Calgary and how it has become a melting pot of different people

Good museum of historical interest. we spent half a day here then walked back into the city centre. The only disappointment was that they were clearing up after the Calgary Stampede event so the grounds were not accessible

The whole reason we stopped here is so that my brother could dress up as a RCMP, he loves the mounties! The museum was well done and the staff were very friendly. Sadly we couldn't go out to the actual part of the fort due to some festivities that had it gated off.

We visited Fort Calgary and thought it was a great representation of how the Fort began.The museum is not huge, however easily navigated with small displays of the different services of the day. As you enter each display an audio recording commences outlining an activity for that service (doctor, newspaper etc) of the day.The museum also has a...
Very informative displays about the history of Calgary and the establishment of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

Not sure how this place ended up on a top 10 list of things to do in Calgary. But it did so we went. It was easy to find and is very close to a beautiful river walk. When paying our entry fee we were served by a young woman who asked where we were from, I'm guessing "Toronto" was...
Interesting little museum about how Calgary got started. Short film and then a walk around the areas to show what it would have looked like way back then. Worth a visit.

Went here hoping to learn even more about the RCMP than I already did but was disappointed in that respect. Given that this is a reconstructed example of the real thing it didn't grab my interest the way Fort Walsh did in the Cypress Hills in southwestern Saskatchewan. That is worth the three and a half hour trip. This is...

Walked here along the river bank, very interesting museum. The displays are all excellent and the two guys manning the Mounties exhibition were very friendly we chatted to them for ages, One of them Jerry even gave us a lift to the Zoo as his shift there had finished, nice people the Canadians!
Very interesting visit made as interactive as possible. I loved being able to try on a Mounties uniform. Constantly being modernised and expanded.
At the time we visited the fort was nearly empty. Staff were very friendly and made our visit pleasant. The tour of the fort was tailored to the few of us that were there. Worth a visit.
This place is located in Downtown Calgary. It is a museum of Calgary's history. Entrance is $12 for adults and 7 for kids. It is a place to go if it is raining or you are a big lover of history.

What a wonderful reception I received when visiting Fort Calgary with my parents this year. The staff were welcoming and very personable.I liked the museum, I preferred the side with the exhibits rather than the walls of writing. However it is very informative and this is only my personal opinion.A nice introduction into the History of the area....

We stopped by this place as one of the stop of the Round The Block Calgary city tours. The place is wonderful and gives you a real good idea of how the foundation of the city was laid. Nice environment with plenty of parking.

This was good value for the cost of admission. We only had one afternoon in Calgary so we walked to the fort from our hotel, a good bit of well needed exercise and we enjoyed the time spent looking at the exhibitions. About a 40 minute walk from The International Hotel.
The Fort was full of history and exhibits of the past. Staff was very friendly and the exhibits were in a cool and clean environment.

We went for brunch with 5 adults and 3 children to celebrate a birthday and Father's Day. There was a wide variety of beautifully presented food as well as additional items you could order from the menu. The museum was included in the price of the brunch and we spent well over an hour looking at artifacts displayed in various...

Witnessed and elderly female employee tearing a strip off a out of town tour bus driver who happens to let several passengers off to use the washroom. Whoever this employee was has no sense of communication as she was yelling at the out of province bus driver in front of passengers.Someone with a temper like that in the tourism industry...
Visited in early May. The museum is very well organized and gives an excellent overview of the fort and of the North-West Mounted Police and its working with First Nations.

Don't be fooled into thinking this is an actual fort. Yes it is on the grounds of the original fort, however, it no longer stands.That said, this museum is a fantastic way of finding out about Calgary and the history of how it came too be the city it is today.Of particular interest are the comparisons made against...
Well presented , shows the hardships of the early adventurers and settlers all of the displays were informative and allows for imagination of early Canada
A good introduction to Calgary and its history, especially for new visitors to Alberta. Worth doing.
But the exhibits are nice and a really good history of Calgary for everyone. Good for kids, lots of things to see and do.

As first time visitors to Calgary my husband and I found Fort Calgary very interesting and informative on the history of Calgary. The building I believe is a replica of military barracks and is situated inside the Historic Park on the Bow River.
A visit here gives you a good history lesson about this area of Canada. Not too overwhelming, but simply presented for all ages.

Nice little museum with a lot of information to read. The artifacts that were available to see were very good. This is a good place to bring younger kids who are still amazed by the stories and folklore.

We went there expecting to have an hour to look at things. We ended up spending nearly 4 hours. It was great. Coming from overseas it is wonderful to learn other country's history and Fort Calgary is interactive. Great for families.

If you are a visitor to the area, a trip to Fort Calgary will provide you with some interesting information about the origin of the City of Calgary, the role of the RCMP, and the enterprising people who built the city. The site is easily accessed even by foot from the downtown area and the grounds plus the visitor center/museum...
Not the biggest attraction but not expensive. Well worth a visit for some background to Calgary, recommended.

We learned so much about how Calgary actually got its name and start. There is actually a lot to learn here, and do apparently. Their kitchen is surprisingly deep, you can have a great meal there, but I just had some recommended Toffee pudding. You can go put on a suit of the mounted police too. It's free for small...
This place contained the history of Calgary from 1875. Great display of items from the eras. Nice display of room/shop settings

Very informative museum about the RCMP, formerly known as the NWMP, and the city of Calgary. If you're a history buff, you gotta have this on your list. Front Desk staff were very knowledgable and friendly! You could try wearing a mountie uniform and take pics - which was my favourite part. Cool items to bring home too from their...

It has Great history about the City of Calgary. It was fascinating reading about people who came from different countries to build Calgary. I think that children will appreciate the museum - they have created some reading panels that resemble Facebook.
As a first time visitor to Calgary we appreciate the history they presented. It was easy to read, timeline great and video all made for an excellent outing.

We had Easter Brunch today at Fort Calgary and were very pleasantly surprised. Much of a hidden gem, we found the food excellent quality and the service on par with the Fairmont brunches; very pleasant and attentive. My only real complaint is that the brunch was very busy so dishes (which are put out in small quantities to maintain freshness)...

Expensive but at least the displays are well done and you can dress up and take photos wearing various Mountie uniforms.The staff are extremely friendly and yes the alarms go off if you lean in too close to the displays ?

Fort Calgary is a National Historic Site. There is a relatively small museum but it is a lot of fun to visit both for adults and children. Some of the commentary is set up as through it was a series of facebook posts from the historic participants, including a bison! The older children enjoyed this and read more of the...
I've been here twice now and wouldn't hesitate to visit again. Loved the history! I came away each time having learnt something new. Thank you :)

I could see paying two or three dollars for a visit to Fort Calgary. The highlight of the site is to see where the confluence of Calgary's two main rivers. There is ultimately very little about the site that is historical as most of it has been refurbished and restored or totally replaced by new buildings. Having some Mountie presence,...

We went to Fort Calgary for brunch and It was awesome.Very well presented and food was plentiful & delicious.Waiter service was very attentive and polite.After brunch we got a free entrance into the museum which was an added bonus that we did not expect.Give yourself plenty of time as there is a lot to see.

The main floor museum is a credit to the Northwest Mounted Police/Royal Canadian Mounted Police, whose veterans clearly value the displays. The museum caters to all ages with a special effort made to engage the elementary school crowd. And the Sunday brunch, featuring local ingredients, is not to be missed !

Fort Calgary is filled with wonderful, interactive educational exhibits depicting the history of Fort Calgary and the surrounding area. The exhibits are interesting to both children and adults. Take the time to dress up in the Mountie uniforms and take a family photo. Bring a picnic lunch and enjoy a stroll along the river.
If you are new to Calgary it's a must to pay a visit at Fort Calgary to learn about the history of this region. Enjoyable, educational and fun!
Whilst this is agreat museum, it's quite small and doesn;t take too long to get round. I have been there for a wedding and a team building event and both events were really enhance by the venue.

What to do in Calgary on a cold, snowy afternoon? We plumped for Calgary Fort and had a very interesting and informative afternoon.A lot of (dullish) boards set the scene but the recreated scenes were ideal for our group ranging in age from 2 - 66.The staff on duty could not have been more helpful and tolerant of...

I hadn't been here in over 20 years. Wow! Wonderful changes! I wouldn't have recognized the museum, it is totally different place now.I went with a school group that were participating in class activity in the teaching area. The volunteers leading the classes were excellent! Very well versed in the Fort, very personable. I was disappointed with the area...
We have lived in Calgary for almost 20 years and we just recently visited Fort Calgary. Would highly recommend anyone popping in to see what they have. It is a great museum and very well done
Take the time to see how the settlement of Calgary started along with the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. Great history presentation includes a short film.

It is a quaint, smaller venue, so the atmosphere is great - even in a buffet setting. The buffet table is filled with about 15-20 different items, not a lot but what is there is very fresh, sometimes different than what you would get and there is lots. There is the basic sunday brunch items, and your eggs, waffles, etc.....
Walked from downtown Calgary and were very surprised by our welcome and the interesting exhibits. Disappointed that the video seemed to run on restricted times.Worth a visit.

We started our trip by vising Fort Calgary. The staff are friendly and knowledgeable. The exhibits are updated and show a good history of the area. This is a good place to visit for both adults and kids. There are walking trails outside so you can explore the area.

In the hour it takes to walk through you'll learn exactly how Calgary started, how old it is, and who the major figures are. There are some interesting items on display, from hospital tools to a radio station. And a 9 minute video gives the summary so you can tell your friends.

This is a great day trip no matter what day or time of the week. It is a really authentic recreation of the way fort life was really like. Get into the swing of things by dressing up in period clothing and explore the interactive activities to show you how to really be a pioneer!
In calgary there are not so may tourist attractions. This is one worthwhile to visit. The royal canadian mountan police at its best
I was pleasantly suprised when I brought some foreigners to Fort Calgary. I found the exhibits engaging and very modern for telling history in new ways. It was great for people of all ages!

The room designated for the luncheon is spacious which allows ample seating. A PA system is always available and is necessary because of the size of the room. The lunch served is very tasty and tastefully presented.

We were here on a tour, with 35 others, on our way from downtown Calgary to Banff.As one other reviewer said, great way to spend a few hours in Calgary.Interesting to see some of the history, RCMP background, and how the people lived in the old days, when it was a form of 'Wild West'.

i have been to the fort in lethbridge and the fort in fort macleod, so seeing fort calgary was not a new or novel experience for me. It is more professionally ran than the other 2 forts in southern alberta, but pretty much the same scenery and educational information available here.

On our last day in Canada, after dropping our hirecar off in downtown , we walked just over a mile to Fort Calgary. There was a 25% off coupon in our hotel lobby making admission only $9 each too. Staff were lovely, great exhibits and you can even dress up as a Mountie . We even played a game of...
Lovely place for the upcoming eddying of my BFF. Historical significant rooms and friendly and accommodating staff.

My husband and I, who are out-of-towners, visited Fort Calgary to gain some knowledge about the history of Calgary. We were not disappointed! The museum winds its way around various exhibits that tell Calgary's story, starting with the lives of the native people of Alberta and ending on modern-day facts. In addition to these indoor exhibits, you can walk to...
Very nice historic memoribilia. Neat to see the era comparison with the United States. Looked like part was under construction can't wait to see what's next

column3: Cockenzie and Port Seton, null, United Kingdom
column4: An excellent museum offering insights into the history of Calgary and the NW Canadian Mounted Police. Beautifully recreated rooms, houses, stores, etc, offer background to a city which is not much more than 100 years old. It also offers plans of the imaginative developments for the wider site. Full of informative and fun photo opportunities, and the chance to dress...

My husband and I came out here with 51 other seniors with Brewster Tours. We were visiting Calgary on this rainy day. At Fort Calgary there wasn't much to see mostly because of the rain. But nevertheless it would be great to do the tour (which we didn't do) and listen to all the history. The original fort is no...
I went for breakfast. It was delicious. Not a huge selection of food, but still good. The museum was very informative.

It was an average attraction because there was little to see especially if you don't like to read the posters on the walls. Actually even if you like to read, it is difficult to relate all the posters together. I advice to wait 1 year or 2 years to visit as they are building a replica of the original Fort....

I enjoyed Brunch here earlier in the year with friends so was excited to share the experience with my Dad who was visiting from Australia. The buffet brunch includes items you can order fresh from the kitchen and an omelette and egg station. The food is delicious and includes a number of items not generally found in brunch buffets. After...
In this museum the visitor will find informations about the life of old Calgarian before 100 years and how did they live their lives at that time .

When I first saw Fort Calgary, I was a little bit underwhelmed to be honest, but after a 45 mnute visit, I had changed my opinion - it was really interesting!It is a small, unremarkable building on huge empty grassy grounds - as I said underwhelming - but once you get up close and start to read the displays,...
Close to the downtown with free parking, this museum is packed with great info and displays. Lots of history not only about the fort but also about Calgary itself.

Fort Calgary is an interesting spot at the confluence of the Elbow & Bow rivers downtown surrounded by pathways and parkland. They often use the area for outdoor concerts and events in the summer. It's a nice building, lots of interesting artifacts to check out and friendly staff to help guide your visit. A short walk from downtown along the...
Very well done. If you want to know a lute history of Calgary it is worth a visit. If you go around back to see more you have to go across the river. They forgot to tell us that.

Absolutely loved this place. Really liked the boomtown segment though I wish it was a bit longer. The theater area was closed for renovations during my visit so it may have given me the extra little bit to make it feel not as short. The early history segment gave a good prelude leading into the boomtown area.
This gives a good insight into both the history of Calgary and the Mounties. It's informative and well laid out at a modest cost. The staff are very friendly, chatty and welcoming.

cycling alongside bow river on your way to Inglewood takes you alongside Fort Calgary: the birthplace of Calgary.Nice area and an interesting exhibition (some parts even outside!).Have a look at the scarecrow in the garden.

We've been here for Canada Day (musical and educational), brunch (yummy) and for Family Day (loved the cabane a sucre!). The only issue I had was at the brunch where they used latex gloves to put ingredients in the omelets, so I had to miss out on them, in case there was any latex dust contaminating all of the bowls...
A very well done history of the Fort, the development of Calgay and the opening of Western Canada, a great spot for children.
Cute museum about the early history and founding of the city. Like all Canadian Museums they feature items about women in the area.

This was a nice surprise. The exhibits were very good and the information provided in an informative and interesting way. Loved the displays of homes, shops and businesses. Very happy that we took the time to explore.
Fun for the entire family to walk around and see the artifacts and a movie which will show in the theater. A little store as you leave has interesting items and at a fair price.

Fort Calgary is a museum built on the site of the original Fort at the confluence of the Bow and Elbow rivers. It houses an excellent historical reference covering the early settlers, the acquisition of lands from First Nations indigenous people and its development as a major city in Alberta. There are re-creations of shops, a hospital ward, a jail,...

My last visit here was with my sons grade 4 class. We have visited here a few times on special occasions and my son enjoyed it as he got to go on a RCMP mystery quest so he had to look for clues at the various exhibits. The whole experience takes around 2 hours top to finish.

Wasn't sure at first about visiting, but found the birthplace of Calgary and the Mounted Police to be very interesting from an English persons perspective. Its a bit difficult to find the entrance but once inside, there were lots of displays and info, you can dress as a Mountie and take your own picture, and Ruth, the lovely lady who...

column3: Rio de Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
column4: I was there in October 2011. It's a really interesting place to visit. There were no crowd which was great. You can put some outfits on and even enter into a cell. There is a lot to learn about history there.

An interesting way to pass 2 hours in Calgary. Informative but fairly basic aimed more at school parties . We spoke to Tim, a retired Mountie, and he had some good stories to tell and he was also exhibiting some of his painting and photos. Unfortunately there was no refreshments available, and as we had walked the scenic river path...

This self guided tour takes you through the history of the RCMP in Calgary. It is very informative, has lots of learning AIDS and dress up opportunities, and the movie theatre is a nice touch.All flat so suitable for wheelchairs and strollers. Nice paths outside. Great for all ages.

Very informative and an easy self tour. Take time to read the displays and look at the artifacts and photos and you will gain a new appreciation of how it was in the beginning as well as what Calgary means to the citizens. A proud history of hard work and sacrifice. Many of the displays have an automatic audio playback...

Great location to go for your Saturday or Sunday brunch, the room is located on the second floor of this establishment with plenty space between white dressed tables, larges windows give a nice bright open space feeling.The food is of high quality, selection to please every gourmets juices, juices / champagne, tea and coffee, choice of carefully selected salads,...

I really love the layout of the old barracks. The history is explained through a Facebook-like display which would definitely appeal to the mass public. Getting to walk into a house or the kitchen or the cells is a really great touch. Lots of interactive exhibits! The gift shop was very disappointing though.

If you have been to any U.S. history museum and or town that host like Silver Dollar City or even visit old towns you would notice that the road system is set up as to not direct you to have to go through subdivisions to get to a main road unlike Calgary. For some reason the idiots that designed the...

This is a 100year old fort started by the mounties .It is full of history that you have no idea about till you go and seeThere is a introductory movie Very interesting and a bit o fun.The displays are good for the young and the not so young at heart AND great fun for all is some...

If you are new to Calgary or just visiting this province and want some more detailed history then you came to the right place . Here you will see and find the history and some buildings to explore and learn as you go along your adventure of history. Fun for the family or history buff.

Well worth visiting. Nice touch that they let you dress up in Mountie costumes and have your pic taken. Really interesting museum despite this being a fairly new country in terms of heritage. We walked from the train station at City Hall which takes 10 to 15 minutes. On the walk back you get a good view of Calgary Tower.
Really nice place. No that big but still interesting. A lots of equipments and interesting documents. Best for person who like the history and museums.Enjoy!

I got to see the Fort and enjoy the Christmas Craft Fair at the same time. The Fort was a winter wonderland of mostly cottage industry merchants displaying their wares. Nothing you can buy in a store and truly a unique experience.

Take your time going there because there is lots to read. We were there for the Family Day event and it was pretty crowded. They had a few nice games and a craft for the kids. The staff was mostly friendly. Only one thing I didn't like. They provided hay rides for that day. However, nowhere was written that the...

We were a party of 8 celebrating birthdays at the Fort Calgary Sunday Brunch. In a word "fantastic"! Not a huge selection but everything was top quality and delicious. You could also order different varieties of eggs Benedict and french toast from the kitchen. This is a great idea as they don't serve well from a buffet. Scones and cinnamon...
a great place to visit, Fort Calgary's history is very interesting, especially its Scottish influences from the many colourful characters in its past.

I have lived in Calgary a long time and didn't check out Fort Calgary until this past summer. I was amazed at the amount of interactivity they offered, which just adds to the stories they have posted. The ability to see and feel the items from the early settler days is astounding, and really makes one appreciate all the modern...

We visited Fort Calgary as part of our tour. We found it to be very interesting and a great way to learn about the history of the Royal Canadian mounted Police. This was our first trip to western Canada and the Rockies, so there was a lot to learn.

Hands down the best brunch in Calgary at just over $25 for all-you-can-eat and admission to the museum included.Sure the museum isn't huge, but on a cold day, there's just enough here to keep the little ones engaged.

What a great welcome! Dee's bubbly welcome made you feel quite at home in this amazing historical building! Children in Calgary certainly have a great place to learn all about their history and beginnings of the RCMP! A very well laid out collection incorporating the old fort with new building is a delight to explore! Plenty of chances to have...
Only a few mins walk from downtown and its a great history lesson walk thro the area of orginal fort and do the museum which give a good experence of old Calgary.

I made a trip to Fort Calgary expecting to simply see just another RCMP fort in southern Alberta. My visit turned out to be a pleasant surprise when I got there and seen that there was much more than that. The first hallway that it set up to teach you the history of the fort is set up much like...

As a Brit in town for the hockey I had some time to kill and I visited this museum originally to discover why Calgary had developed in its present place. The outside of the building is quite bland with three wooden buildings on a large patch of grass but don't be deceived because inside you will be so impressed with...

Fort Calgary is where it all started and so is worth a visit for this reason alone. But the museum is well laid out and provides an interesting story of the genesis and development of the city up to the early 20th Century. Great for children but plenty for adults. Very easy to follow and assimilate. The narrative boards for...
If you are short on time, want a quick intro to Calgary's history, near downtown Calgary and The Heritage Park is closed- this place would be a good option.
A good way to learn about the history of the Mounted Police and the growth of Calgary in an informative and interactive way. Small shop at the attraction but no caf.

We meant to just stop in to have a look around for about an hour, but ended up being there for about 4 hours.The way that some of the information at the start of the museum was slightly off putting at first, as they used a kind of social media format, ie, Historical Figure XX commented on a photo...
Interesting look at the establishment and growth of an outpost that grew to be the city of Calgary. Would recommend to anyone with an interest in history.

The entry fee is fairly inexpensive and well worth it! When you first enter the museum there is lots of information on story boards to read, which gets boring after awhile, but very interesting & informative. We found the second section of the museum wonderfully designed and displayed! We Loved reading all the info about Alberta's oil discovery & boom!...
I was the first visitor in the morning, hence the museum was empty, it's very informative and the exhibits are well themed for all the family. Love the opportunity to put on the mounty suit

I enjoyed my time here, It is obvious that they have put a lot of work into making this a nice atmosphere and a good learning experience.I think one of the big downsides, and I don't want to criticize them for this because it was a preference thing, is the way they present a lot of information. They have...
Great place to have a festival right in the city. The field was very spacious. Wish the second stage was a lot bigger though. It's a bit small for the crowd that they are aiming for.

I ended up arriving in Calgary on the august long weekend, and the c-train was not running and some of the other places I had planned to visit were closed. I moved this visit up to Monday and discovered, for that day, it was free. I have been here before and enjoyed this visit just as much.was hoping more...

When I first thought of going to Fort Calgary, I thought it would just be a bunch of barracks in an open field. However, it was much more than that. There is a large interpretive centre that is full of information and videos. It focuses a lot on the NWMP and not so much on the history of Calgary. I...

Fort Calgary is a very small place with too many unrelated pictures and long stories about common Canadians, with very little interest. There were about four small rooms with artifacts that were set up like living exhibits, but the place itself feels too school-oriented and would have little appeal for adult tourists.

Lots of history on the site of the founding place of Calgary. Nice new and reconstructed buildings. The information is all there, though it's almost all on readerboards. I must say, though, that the reader boards make clever use of mock Face Book style. Good view of the city and the river when walking around outside.

I'm not particularly a history person, but enjoyed this visit. Parts of the museum are more interesting than others. I enjoyed the replica rooms/shops/quarters etc. it was informative and told the story well. I also enjoyed walking round outside, looking at where the old railway run,.The 10 minute film in the theatre at the end was also good and...

There was an excellent film presentation and talk on the history of what began as the North-West Mounted Police, before becoming the RCMP, and the reasons for their presence in Calgary. The tour continues with recreations of the settings in which they worked. Retired members of the force were there to answer further question. Uniforms can be tried on, though...

This museum is intended to provide a history of Calgary's early days, particularly from the perspective of the role of the North West Mounted Police, later the RCMP, the arrival of the railroad and finally Calgary's early missteps and finally explosive development as the Oil Capital of Canada.One day with more thought (and money) it will achieve that objective....

Went here as part of a tour and found it to be really interesting. It is set up like a museum with lots of mini shop fronts and displays. Also a small house display.There is RCMP uniforms there which are available for you to put on and have your photo taken.

Fort Calgary was originally built in 1875 by the North West Mounted Police, became the birthplace of the City of Calgary. The fort was decommissioned in 1914 and the land sold to developers. The site was reclaimed in 1975 and cleared of development to become a public park with an interpretive centre. It is an historic site federally, for the...
A good introduction into the birth of Calgary. Exhibits were decent. Probably most interesting for Canadians.
Very well presented, really gives you a flavour of the how Calgary was born. Very helpful and pleasant staff. Unfortunately Deane House was closed for renovations.

The exhibition, which details the forming of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, is very enjoyable and interesting. Whilst we were there a medal ceremony was taking place and it was nice to see all the 'Mounties; in their dress uniforms.

The Fort Calgary exhibition is brilliant! Through artifacts and commentary, they bring the history of Calgary and the RCMP in the NW Territories to life. The "Facebook-style" presentation was especially compelling. And the center staff do a great job of helping kids get engaged with the story, too. We'll done.

Very historic, lovely place lots of Calgary history, makes you think about riding a horse 100 years ago. Very strong people started this and look what we did, tore most of it down except we saved the most oldest wood hotel. The infamous King Eddy - sure miss that place. Who do you think your trying to kid by redoing...

We found the visit quite interesting as it details the forming of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. We began with a short introductory talk & film, men were chosen to 'model' the uniforms & then we wandered the various rooms & displays.The general theme is that the RCMP got on well with the native Indians - but as they...

It looked interesting from the outside. But I should've listened to the reviews here on Trip Advisor. For one thing, the map we were given didn't label the party rooms where some companies were having team building events. Hubby & I almost stumbled into one because of that. The Interpretive Center itself is very small. There were a bunch of...

The bison just inside the entrance was so promising. But the rest of the museum failed to reach its potential in bringing alive the riveting history of the First Nations inhabitants before and shortly after European contact, the European settlement and its attendant conflicts between ranchers and farmers, betrayal of the First Nations, and interference by the first Canadian Prime...
This is not a fort. It's a museum with exhibits and pictures. Totally not worth it!They charge $12 to get in. The only thing my husband and I did was to play pool at the pool table there.
For an overview of Calgary's history, as well as how The Mounties developed, this was almost faultless. Thank you!

Visited on Sunday morning of the August long weekend. Easy to find, meet by a very helpful and friendly Receptionist who gave very clear instructions to help us start our visit. The fascinating timeline takes you from the earliest days to the future plans for the area and puts everything in context.Very informative and well laid out, definitely worth a...

Fort Calgary is a restored fort/museum telling the history of Calgary, the mounties and the conflict with the first nation inhabitants (Indians).A short walk from the bus stop. Easily reached from downtown Calgary.Reasonably priced, with reductions for OAPs and children.A date sequenced museum illustrating the inauguration of the mounties and demise of the buffaloA film show...

Visited twice with various senior members of my family. The attraction provides an interesting history of the establishment of Calgary and is a good introductory attraction for visitors and recently arrived residents of Canada. The staff (some are ex-Mounties!!) are very knowledgeable and helpful. There is an opportunity to dress up as Mounties, which is fun for everyone. Entry fee...

The small museum is set in a very large parkland. It tells the story of the Mounted Police and the beginning of the town of Calgary. In 1875 the North West Mounted Police(NWMP) was created, and in 1904 it was renamed the Royal North West Mounted Police (RNWMP). Finally in 1920, it was again renamed the Royal Canadian Mounted Police...

Easy to follow time line, good selection of interesting exhibits. One staff member gave us a listing of things we might like to stop and see on our trip which we found extremely useful. We saw most of them. Unfortunately we cant remember her name. I wish we had written it down.

Had a great time at the fort - the displays are very well done and it is much larger than it first appears. We were there for Mountie Day and it was a lot of fun - there were a few extra things like face painting and a craft for the kids as well as cake for all guests. The...

I was at Fort Calgary for a young lady's birthday party. I couldn't believe how well they are organized for such an event. A coordinator will take care of 15-20 young children and keep them occupied for almost 1 1/2 hours.The facility is well maintained and the children thoroughly enjoyed their stay. They learned about the development of the...

Located east of downtown on 9th Avenue SE, the exhibits at 40-acre Fort Calgary are magnets for local school field trips and nave tourists curious about local history  after all, its a stop on Albertas Old Forts Trail. On my visit, so many buses were disgorging children and tour groups that I only wandered the grounds on mostly unpaved...

The centre is on the grounds of the original fort and is a great history lesson however there is lots of reading and I got quite tired after a short while. Lots of information to take in and all very interesting but I don't see why they need to charge an admission fee.

Fort Calgary is a replica of the barracks built a few hundred years ago. There is a museum inside it which is an ideal place to take kids to visit. Its medium size makes it not too much for kids to roam around as well as provides for great experiential learning. Some of the unique hotspots of the forts are;...
A good review of the early years in Calgary. Close to downtown - could walk. Other areas of interest are also nearby.
I attended a nephew's wedding here and it was a beautiful setting. the catering for the reception was very good.
Lots of stuff to see and do .. great for the kids...If your kids are in about grade 3 or 4 they will see lots of there social studies curriculum

By the description you expect to see a fort but all you have is a small museum which takes about an hour to go round. No food on sale only cold drinks or tea and coffee via hot water flasks. Also the buses to get there and back do not run very often.

We were able to see all of the exhibits in a short time (2-3 hours). Well laid out and with well informed staff throughout.Got good history of the formation of Calgary as a fort and as emerging city.Good historical and cultural snapshot and a place to visit if you have limited time in the city.Also just a...

Not sure what I was expecting from this but was disappointed. Thought there might be more than there was on the local history of the Mounted Police. Large exhibition on how life change for the people of Calgary over the years.

We went here on Heritage day in August when it was free entry. We spent about 2 hours there and my 5 year old child enjoyed it as there were plenty of special things happening on that day (face painting,etc). But regardless, even on a 'normal' day there was enough there to entertain a little lad for a hour or...
this was not at all what i expected. great for lil kids but i wouldn't waste my money here, it was only 10.00

More of a museum than a fort but it does contain a lot of interesting historical information about the building of Calgary and it's history. Unfortunately I think it needs a review of how they provide this information - a short 'magic lantern' show and 9 minute video was not enough to set the scene for the displays. I found...
Dont bother...I don't know how this has such high ratings. It was boring. A lot of the buildings we couldn't even go into...just look at. We drove fromEdmonton just to see it. I regret it.

Easy location from downtown Calgary - a 5 minute drive - plenty of parking. Well put together museum about turn of the century Calgary. Spent 2 hours there. Don't forget to try on a Mountie coat and see the Deane House.

Not really much of a fort, more a museum, rather a good one, of the Royal Mounted police and their history. Bus no 1 from the city centre.There are a couple of replica buildings which you can see without entering the museum itself. However, it was good to see all the displays and history of how the Mounties came...
You can learn just as much from the plaques outside for free without paying the high admission price!

A very interesting insight into the history of the Fort and Calgary. Very helpful lady selling the tickets. Need a good 2 hours here to see everything. $22 for 2 adults. They also gave us a voucher for the Heritage Historical Village which was very useful.

If you want a hands on type history lesson about Calgary this is the place. The Supervisor of the front desk was an older lady who was loudly dissing some of her staff that we heard - she was not professional and seemed snotty. The younger gals working were very pleasant and made our visit nice. Smoking security guards standing...
We spent a very good couple of hours at Fort Calgary. Very informative on local Calgary and of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. There are hands on things to do and can even dress up.

Downtown with free parking. Use your AAA/CAA/NRMA auto Association membership for a discount. Inside it was quiet but extremely family friendly with lots of hands on activities for everyone. They encourage dressing up in RCMP uniforms for photographs -no fee, period costume for a car photo-no fee. The changing exhibits included paint a bison and hundred had. Rooms are well...
I cant wait to see what Fort Calgary does to expand the history telling with the new donation!We did enjoy our time there and hope for a little more next time!

We had some time to kill before heading to the airport for a later afternoon flight. It was easy to get to by auto and certainly not busy on a mid-June Sunday visit. Displays are well laid out and documented. Staff were helpful. Good overview of the birth and development of Calgary and the NWMP/RCMP.
Learn about Indian history. Guides very helpful.Oldtime displays very nice. Also nice gift shop.
Always enjoyed heading here to waste some time. Nothing terribly excited, but good place to spend with the family. Inexpensive!!!
We had trouble finding the museum. The museum was interesting but we felt it was overpriced. The buildings outside were not worth walking to.
I learned a lot during my first visit there. Staffs were friendly and very knowledgable

We found this museum to the NWMP and RCMP to be insightful and staffed by friendly staff. Yes I do have to say that I felt it to be overpriced, but as a lifelong fan of the RCMP it is well worth the visit.Speaking to our Calgarian friends they at times appear embarrassed about their perceived lack of history...
we were there for a corporate function but were allowed access to all the exhibits. It is really interesting to see how the NWMP braved very harse conditions to open the West.
Went for the Easter egg hunt and enjoyed the day. lots of interesting things for peole to see and learn about the history of our city.
If you want to know some Calgary history this is a great start.
interesting for kids, lots of history of the early days
the history is great, but I just can't afford more than one visit in a lifetime
A little bit of history, well preserved and presented. Very well worth a visit, particularly on Canada Day.

Although living in Calgary for 34 yrs,i've never been to Fort Calgary before.We had to attend a work luncheon/meeting and after showing up a little early,were able to walk around a little bit.The displays are well put together i thought and the staff were very helpful with any questions.I didn't have the time i would've liked but from what i...

went there for a Company Function . A Murder Mistery and a Buffet. The Play was entertaining , but the Dinner Buffet was fantastic. A Selection of Salads and Hot Entree's with my favorite Roast Beef , which was simply to die for. My Compliments to the Chef.... The Service was also exellent , fast and very friendly. Something to...
Artifacts abound! One of the highlights was sitting in an old tram car. It's mostly walking around an viewing, there is not a lot of hands on but it gives a good overview of the history of Calgary
Its definitely worth the effort to see. It is our heritage.

When Col. Macleod of the Northwest Mounted Police Sent a troop- to establish a Fort it was at the confluence of the Bow and Elbow rivers that was chosen. Over the years the fort was lost to industrial building and became part of an extensive railway yard. As this was taken back the city decided to restore the fort on...
The volunteers do awesome work to help out around the place. The maintaince department has done a great job at upkeep and were so helpful with the history of the building.

We went here before we had a family, and it was fun then too! There were quite a few interactive displays, and lots of places to take pictures (with props!). I thought it was an interesting way to learn about the settlement and fur-trade history of the Calgary area. It only takes an hour, or two, and has some outdoor...

The site where Calgary was founded by the North West Mounted Police - the precursor of the RCMP. Well documented exhibits and faithfully reconstructed buildings depicting life in Western Canada in the alte 19th century. Situated at the Junction of the Elbow and Boe Rivers in downtown modern Calgary

After shopping in Calgary's downtown, I saw the fort as a change of pace. I took the lightrail half way and walked the rest of way. An easy walk that is gratifying when you see the fort. Inside I found a museum full of facts and interactive displays that kids and adults would love. I walked away feeling like I...

The main building at Fort Calgary houses a museum with a nice layout and very good interpretive displays. Many of the displays are unique, and several are interactive. Outside, the fort site is not much to see - a reconstructed example of a fort wall and a couple of locked buildings. In that regard, Fort McLeod greatly overshadows Fort Calgary....

After reading some reviews about this place I was wondering what the deal was so I wife and I decided to check it out. It a neat place to visit, I might not recommend it for young kids, unless they like to read about the history of Calgary and Fort Calgary. I'll admit that some of the stuff is boring...
Really enjoyed looking at the quaint little rooms and reading the history. Audio came on automatically in some rooms to add to the feeling. One of the better small history museums I have seen

We planned to go inside this morning (27.6.2011). We went into the souvenir shop to have a look first before buying the tickets. We accidentally left the shop at the exit that link to the paid area (which is very misleading and without any signs). The staff shouted at us rudely saying that we are not permitted to go inside...

Excellent place to visit away from the hustle and bustle of the city so peaceful. You can walk along the river to this at a slow pace in about 30 mins from downtown. The tour took one hour and was really good cannot recommend more highly. The quaint house next door is excellent for a spot of lunch and the...

My family and I went to visit Fort Calgary in May 2010 and believe me, not worth it it all! It is a scam and I would not even waste time there if it was free....and of course, it's not! You will pay about 11$ per person to see a 10 minutes movie which is barely audible, not educationna and...

Attended Fort Calgary for a special event: Spring into Easter with my 2 children ages 5 and 6. Both my kids and I were disappointed. Although the entry was free for the kids my entry to the attractions cost $11. My disappointment is two fold: Poor planning for the kids activities. There was one face painter on site who did...

We visited Fort Calgary in the winter when the outside part is closed. The inside part is quite interesting with displays about the founding of Calgary and stuff about the Mounties etc, but I think the outside part is probably more interesting (from what I could see in the brochure/postcards). To be fair the price is considerably reduced in the...
